title: Attempts
custom_steps:
1. Press play on a video.
2. As soon as the main content starts playing, check the "Attempts" metric on Pulse.
custom_expected:
Pulse> 
When the main content starts playing, Dashboards --> Real-time --> "Attempts" = "1". 
Note: Even in case of Exit Before Video Start and Video Start Failure, when the session is cleaned up, we should see "Attempts" on Pulse = "1".

title: Concurrent Plays
custom_steps:
1. Press play on a video.
2. When the content is playing (after pre-roll), check the "Concurrent Plays" metric on Pulse.
custom_expected:
Pulse> 
When the content is playing, Dashboards --> Real-time --> "Concurrent Plays" = "1".

title: Video Startup Time (with Buffering)
custom_steps:
1. Use a tool (like Charles proxy) to throttle the CDN to a low bandwidth setting (eg: 200Kbps).
2. Press play on the video.
3. Wait for video to load (buffer) for 10 seconds, then release the throttle.
4. When video starts playing, check the "Video Startup Time" metric in Touchstone and Pulse.
custom_expected:
"Video Startup Time" should be displayed (in seconds) as the time between the user hitting play and the main content starting, including the initial buffering time.
 
Pulse> 
"Video Startup Time" should be displayed (in seconds) as the time between the user hitting play and the main content starting, including the initial buffering time.

title: Video Startup Time (VST) with pre-roll
custom_steps:
1. Press play on a video which has a pre-roll.
2. Once the pre-roll finishes and main content starts playing, check the "Video Startup Time" metric in Touchstone and Pulse.
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
Client Side Ads:
"Video Startup Time" should be displayed (in seconds) as the time between the user hitting play and the main content starting, excluding the pre-roll duration.
Server Side Ads:
"Video Startup Time" should be displayed (in seconds) as the time between the user hitting play and the first frame of pre-roll being displayed to the user.
 
Pulse>
Client Side Ads:
"Video Startup Time" should be displayed (in seconds) as the time between the user hitting play and the main content starting, excluding the pre-roll duration.
Server Side Ads:
"Video Startup Time" should be displayed (in seconds) as the time between the user hitting play and the first frame of pre-roll being displayed to the user.

title: Playing Time
custom_steps:
1. Press play a video.
2. While the main content is playing, check Touchstone and "Average % Complete" metric on Pulse.
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
1. Verify that the monitoring session is in "Playing" state when the main content is playing.
2. Verify that the "Playing Time" increases with every heartbeat.
 
Pulse>
When the main content is playing, Dashboards --> Device Validation (select your session) --> "Average % Complete" metric should increase with every heartbeat.

title: Paused Time
custom_steps:
1. Press play on a video.
2. Once the main content starts playing, press the "Pause" button.
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
1. Verify that the monitoring session reports change to "Paused" state when user presses pause button.
2. Verify that the 'Playing time' stops increasing and the "Paused time" starts increasing.
 
Pulse>
Monitoring session in Pulse should be maintained even if video is in Paused state.

title: Error reporting for Video Start Failure (VSF)
custom_steps:
1. Use a web proxy tool (like Charles proxy) and configure a HTTP status 403 response to the video URL request for the manifest file.
2. Play the specific video, whose manifest has been blocked.
 
Note: 
(i) ‘Blacklist’ feature in Charles can be used to configure a 403 response. 
   
(ii) An alternate method is to ‘Map-remote’ the streamURL to a non-existent host (eg: foobar.com)
custom_expected:
Touchstone> 
1. When the user presses play, a new monitoring session should be created.
2. When the video fails to play (due to blocked request URL), a fatal error should be reported to Conviva library. 
Note: if the player has retry logic, all the retries (and their respective failure messages) should be reported in this same monitoring session. i.e. a new monitoring session should not be created for each retry.

title: Error reporting for Video Playback Failure (VPF)
custom_steps:
1. Press play on a video.
   
2. While the main content is playing, use a web proxy tool (like Charles proxy) to configure a HTTP status 403 response to the video URL request
 
Note:
(i) ‘Blacklist’ feature in Charles can be used to configure a 403 response.
(ii) An alternate method is to ‘Map-remote’ the streamURL to a non-existent host (eg: foobar.com)
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
1. When the user presses play, a new monitoring session should be created and the player states and events should start getting reported.
2. When the player runs into an error (due to blocked request URL), a fatal error should be reported to Conviva library.
 
Note: if the player has retry logic, all the retries (and their respective failure error messages) should be reported in this same monitoring session. i.e. a new monitoring session should not be created for each ret

title: Session cleanup after VSF and VPF
custom_steps:
1. As documented in the VSF and VPF test cases, block the stream/request URL to trigger a fatal error (before playback for VSF, and mid-stream for VPF)
2. Once the fatal error is reported and the player has exhausted all retries, check if the monitoring session is cleaned up.
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
1. Once the fatal error is reported and the player has exhausted all retries, the monitoring session should be cleaned up.
2. The 'Session Status' should be displayed as 'Video Start Failure' (for VSF case) and 'Video Playback Failure' (for VPF case) .

title: Exit Before Video Starts (EBVS)
custom_steps:
1. Press play on a video.
2. Exit the video (eg: by pressing the back button) before the first frame appears on screen.
custom_expected:
Touchstone> 
1. When the user presses play, a new monitoring session should be created.
2. When the user exits the video, the monitoring session should be cleaned up and the "Session Status" should be reported as "Exit Before Video Start".
 
Pulse>
When the user exits, Dashboard --> Real-time --> "Exit Before Video Start" --> this metric should show 100% and "Attempts" should show "1".

title: Bitrate
custom_steps:
1. Press play on a video.
2. Once the video starts playing at the highest bitrate, trigger a bitrate drop (by using a proxy tool like Charles proxy) to throttle down the bandwidth to CDN to a lower value (eg: 1000-1500Kbps).
3. Once the video switches to lower bitrate, unthrottle the network to let the video play again at highest bitrate.
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
1. When the main content starts playing, verify that "Bitrate" value is displayed.
2. When the video switches to lower bitrate, verify that "Bitrate" value displays the new value.
3. When the video switches to higest bitrate, verify that "Bitrate" value displays the new value.
 
Pulse>
1. Dashboard --> Real-time --> "Average Bitrate" --> this metric should show the average bitrate of the playback stream when the video is playing.
2. Dashboard --> Real-time --> "Average Bitrate" --> this metric should show a drop in average bitrate when the video switches to a lower bitrate.
3. Dashboard --> Real-time --> "Average Bitrate" --> this metric should show an increase in average bitrate when the video switches to the highest bitrate.

title: Average Frame Rate
custom_preconds: Library/SDK should support Average Frame Rate reporting
custom_steps:
1. Play a video
2. Once the main content starts playing, check if Average Frame Rate (afps) is being reported.
custom_expected:
Touchstone and Pulse>
1. A new session should be created in Touchstone and a new 'Attempt' and 'Concurrent Play' should show up on Pulse.
2. When the video is in 'Playing' state:
- The 'Average FPS' field in Touchstone should show the Average Frame rate. The 'Average Frame Rate' metric on Pulse should also reflect the same value. 
**Note:
(i) If 'Encoded FPS' is not being reported, ensure that 'Average FPS' is close to one of the standard 'Encoded FPS' values like 24fps, 25fps, 30fps, 50fps, 60fps.
(ii) If 'Encoded FPS' is being reported, ensure that 'Average FPS' is not more than 'Encoded FPS'. Also, 'Encoded FPS' should be one of the standard values like 24fps, 25fps, 30fps, 50fps, 60fps.

title: Buffering (due to network conditions)
custom_preconds: Note: if the video is very short, you may need to start the video at lower bandwidth.
custom_steps:
1. Press play on a video.
2. Once the main content starts playing, use a proxy tool (like Charles proxy) to throttle the bandwidth to CDN to a low value (eg: 100-200Kbps).
3. Once the player's buffer runs out, the player will display buffering icon to the user.
4. After 10 seconds, release the throttle so that the video can resume playing.
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
1. When the player's buffer runs out and it displays a buffering icon to the user, verify that the session state is reported as "Buffering". 
2. Verify that the "Buffering time" increases with each heartbeat sent during this time.
3. When the video resumes, verify that the player reports state change from "Buffering" to "Playing". 
 
Pulse>
1. Dashboard --> Real-time --> "Rebuffering Ratio" --> When the video buffers due to slow network connection, you should see a non-zero value here.
2. Dashboard --> Real-time --> "Connection Induced Rebuffering Ratio" --> When the video buffers due to slow network connection, you should see a non-zero value here and it should be same value as "Rebuffering Ratio".

title: Fast Forward and Rewind buttons on player
custom_steps:
1. Play video.
2. Fast forward and rewind the video by using the >> and << buttons on the player.
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
Verify current session is not destroyed.
Verify no new session is created.
Verify the session state is reported correctly as Buffering or Playing (based on what the user sees).
If the library supports 'seek', ensure 'pss' and 'pse' events are reported when seek starts and ends.
Pulse>
Dashboard --> Real-time --> Concurrent Plays --> this value should show "1" to represent the current video playback. Current session should not be destroyed and no new session should be created.
Dashboard --> Real-time --> Rebuffering Ratio --> this value should increase to show buffering (if experienced by the user).
If the library supports 'seek', Dashboard --> Real-time --> Connection Induced Rebuffering Ratio --> this value should not increase.
If the library supports 'seek', Dashboard --> Real-time --> Video Restart Time --> this should report the time taken for video to start playing after the seek operation.

title: Backgrounding
custom_preconds: This test case is not applicable to desktop browser based applications, as the video continues playing even if you minimize the browser.
custom_steps:
1. Play a video.
2. While the video is playing, press the home/xbox/ps button to navigate to the homepage.
3. Launch another app on the same device.
4. Exit this app now.
5. Launch the test app again.
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
1. When video starts to load, a new  session should be created in touchstone
2. When the home/xbox/ps button is pressed and application goes into background, the session should be cleaned up.
3. When the user returns to the test app, if the video auto-resumes, a new session should be created. If the video doesn't auto-resume, no new session should be created until user selects a new video to play.
 
Pulse>
1. When app goes to background: Dashboard --> Real-Time --> Concurrent Plays --> this value should drop to "0"
   
2. When app comes back to foreground: Dashboard --> Real-Time --> Concurrent Plays --> this value will show "1" when a video playback starts

title: Suspend
custom_steps:
1. Play video.
2. Let the video play for about 30seconds.
3. Use the power button on device to put device to sleep (screen off).
4. After about 60sec of screen off, use power button to turn screen ON again.
5. Play the video from where it left off (in some cases the video may auto start)
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
1. Verify the session is cleaned up when the screen is turned off
2. Verify a new session created when the screen is turned back on and if video auto-plays. If the video does not auto-play, a session should be created only when the user presses play.
 
Pulse>
1. When screen turns off: Dashboard --> Real-time --> Concurrent Plays --> this value should drop to "0"
2. When video resumes with screen on: Dashboard --> Real-time --> Concurrent Plays --> this value should increase to "1"

title: Close of Session
custom_steps:
1. Press play on a video.
2. While video is playing, exit the video using following methods:
- Press the Back or Home button on device/controller/remote. 
- Select another video while current video is playing.
- If using Chromecast, 'disconnect' the Chromecast from the casting device.
- If using a Browser, open a new URL (eg: www.google.com) in the same tab where the video is playing.
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
1. When the user presses play, a new monitoring session should be created.
2. When the user exits the video, the monitoring session should be cleaned up and no more heartbeats should be sent in this session.
 
Pulse>
Dashboards --> Real-time --> "Concurrent Plays" --> this metric may change from 1-->0 when the user exits the video. 
Note: Pulse displays average data (over the last 60sec). So, close of one session and start of a new session can show "Concurrent Plays" = 2 for few seconds.

title: End of Session
custom_steps:
1. Play video.
2. Let video play till the end. Note: you can seek the video forward to get closer to end of video.
custom_expected:
Touchstone> 
Verify last HB is sent out and session is Ended. Note: sometimes session will not be cleaned up and will just timeout. It is ok as long as HBs are not constantly sent once the video is finished.
Pulse> 
Dashboard --> Real-time --> Concurrent Plays --> this value should drop to "0" indicating that the session ended cleanly.

title: Content Length / Duration (VOD & Live-Linear)
custom_preconds: Content Length/Duration should be reported in "seconds".
custom_steps:
1. Press play on a video.
2. Once the main content starts playing, check the value of "Content Length" in Touchstone.
custom_expected: Touchstone> Compare the "Content Length" reported in Touchstone to the length shown on the video screen. They should match.

title: Verify support for 'framework version'
custom_preconds: This test case is not applicable in case of Custom Player integration.
custom_steps: 1. Play a video and verify the player 'framework version' against the supported versions on Community (download page).
custom_expected:
Device Validation/Touchstone>
The framework version should be one of the supported versions. If you see a higher version (for any of Major/Minor/Revision), make an internal note to the SC/IE/PM. If we see only Revision# changing, mark this test case as ‘Observation'. If we see either of Minor# or Major# changing, mark this test case as ‘Failed'.

title: Verify support for 'stream protocol'
custom_preconds: This test case is not applicable in case of Custom Player integration.
custom_steps:
1. Play a video.
2. Check the streamURL to identify the stream protocol (HLS, MP4, etc) being used. 
3. Compare against the Conviva library's Tech Spec table available on the Downloads page on Community.
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
The stream protocol being used should be one of the supported protocols listed on Community. If you see an unsupported protocol, fail this test case and make an internal note to the SC/IE/PM.

title: Confirm client library being used is latest
custom_steps:
1. Play a video.
2. Note the Conviva client library version being used. (visible in touchstone)
custom_expected: Compare library version to that on Community website to make sure latest version is being used by the customer. If the latest version is not being used, fail this test and suggest the customer to update to the latest library.

title: Playing Video with mid-roll
custom_steps:
1. Play video.
2. Let the mid-roll play.
3. Let the video play after the mid-roll.
custom_expected:
Touchstone> 
1. Verify that a new session is created when video is played.
2. For client side ads: Verify monitoring is in Not Monitored state during mid-roll. For server side ads: monitoring should continue and player states should be reported during mid-roll. 
3. Verify accurate player state is reported when content resumes after mid-roll.
 
Pulse> 
1. Verify that a new session is created for this attempt.
2. Verify that the session is maintained in Pulse before, during and after the mid-roll.

title: Seek past mid-roll
custom_steps:
1. Play video.
2. Seek the video past the mid-roll and let playback resume.
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
1. Verify that a new session is created when video is played.
2. After user seeks past the mid-roll, if the mid-roll plays, for client side ads: Verify monitoring is in Not Monitored state during mid-roll. For server side ads: monitoring should continue and player states should be reported during mid-roll.
3. Verify accurate player state is reported when content resumes after mid-roll.
 
Pulse>
1. Verify that a new session is created for this attempt.
2. Verify that the session is maintained in Pulse before, during and after the mid-roll.

title: Backgrounding during pre-roll and mid-roll
custom_steps:
1. Play a video which has pre-roll, mid-roll.
2. While the ad is playing, push the app to background (using Home button) [Test for both pre-roll and mid-roll separately].
3. After 15seconds, bring the app to foreground.
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
1. When the app is pushed to background, the session should be cleaned up. 
2. When app is brought to foreground and ad resumes, a new session should be created. Ensure the Video Startup Time of that session is correct (dependng on client side or server side ad).

title: Switching Audio Feeds
custom_preconds:
Need a live or archived game with at least 2 audio feeds
Need Touchstone to view video stream info
custom_steps:
1. Stream a game with at least 2 audio feeds for several minutes (3-5)
2. Select a different audio feed
custom_expected:
1. Conviva shows the start of a session, any buffering/bit rate changes/errors, and streaming
2. Previous session ends and a new session starts (coincides with the audio feed switch) and displays the start of a new session, any buffering/bit rate changes/errors, and streaming

title: Session Reporting
custom_preconds:
This is a Dev Test only!
Use a build in Staging
Log in to Touchstone in Staging
custom_steps:
1. Launch the app
2. Stream archived video
3. Monitor the PS4 in Touchstone
4. Pause video
5. Play video
6. End the video playback
custom_expected:
1. The app launches
2. Video is streaming
3. Touchstone shows:
* asset name
* stream URL
* live status (true/false)
* player (application) name
* viewer ID
* the start of the session
* bit rate
* frame rate
* any buffering
* video duration
4. Touchstone shows the video is paused
5. Touchstone shows the video playback has resumed
6. Touchstone shows the session has ended

title: Replay same video after End of Session
custom_steps:
1. Play a video.
2. Let the video play to the end (end of session). Note: You can scrub the video to move forward quicker.
3. Once the video ends, click 'replay/play' button to play the same video again.
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
Verify initial session ends gracefully when video ends.
Verify new session is created for replayed video attempt.

title: Timers for heartbeats
custom_preconds: This test case is applicable for Custom Player Integrations only
custom_steps:
1. Play a video.
2. Check frequency of Conviva heartbeats
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
Verify that heartbeats are sent out every 5 sec (while proxying through Touchstone).

title: Device storage
custom_preconds: This test case is applicable for Custom Player Integrations only
custom_steps:
1. Play a video.
2. Close the video and reboot the device.
3. Play a video
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
Verify Client ID before and after reboot is the same. i.e. after reboot client should pick up client ID from storage.

title: Metadata set at session creation
custom_steps: 1. Play a video.
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
Check in touchstone to ensure that all the metadata (properties and custom tags) are set at the time of session creation.

title: Device Category ('cat') Device Tags, Required Tags, Custom Tags
custom_steps:
1. Play a video.
2. Verify that the tag with value 'cat' is being reported in platform metadata.
custom_expected:
1. When the main content starts playing, check if the integration is correctly reporting the ‘cat’ tag value under platform metadata.
Example: “cat”: “AND”
{Note that Conviva library converts the below 'id' to upper case}

Ensure all device tags (Device Brand, Model, Browser, Framework, OS, etc) are present in Device Validation.

Ensure all Required tags (Asset Name, CDN/Resource, StreamURL, isLive, Viewer ID, Player 
Name) are reported as expected in Device Validation
 
id="ps" name="PlayStation"

System will auto display all the values set in the metadata template
